text: The number of people hospitalized with COVID-19 in California dropped to 6,753 on Wednesday, health officials reported. The number had been above 6,800 for the past 13 days. However, lower numbers are in part caused by a change in reporting requirements. https://t.co/hpqTfRyqti

name: sfchronicle
text:
RT @DominicFracassa: Breaking: SF officials announce law enforcement de-funding plan: 
-$120M over 2 years from SFPD and Sheriff 
-$40M annually from SFPD (~6% of budget)
-$20M annually from Sheriff (~8% of budget) 

Money to be reinvested in Black community. 

story coming w/@meganrcassidyBreaking: SF officials announce law enforcement de-funding plan:

name: sfchronicle
text: Residents and state officials say the situation in Imperial County shed light on how the coronavirus has disproportionately harmed two vulnerable groups all over California: agricultural workers and the Latino community. https://t.co/lSKX4dJD8T

name: sfchronicle
text: Despite its improvement, Imperial County‚Äôs per capita infection rate since the outset of the pandemic ‚Äî one case for every 19 residents ‚Äî remains the highest in California, by far. It‚Äôs four times the statewide rate. https://t.co/NXTzOzaNLO

name: sfchronicle
text:
"I need my father and my mother."

A 10-year-old Yemeni girl is stranded alone in Egypt after the Trump administration denied her a visa.

Her parents, who recently settled in San Francisco, are desperate to bring her home.

Read more: https://t.co/jAu0WJFJEk https://t.co/txPe4TU06N
